skill.name: pathml
skill.description: Full-featured computational pathology toolkit. Use for advanced WSI analysis including multiplexed immunofluorescence (CODEX, Vectra), nucleus segmentation, tissue graph construction, and ML model training on pathology data. Supports 160+ slide formats. For simple tile extraction from H&E slides, histolab may be simpler.
skill.summary: Full-featured computational pathology toolkit. Use for advanced WSI analysis including multiplexed i...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: PathML is a legitimate open-source computational pathology toolkit. All 554 static findings are false positives - the scanner detected patterns in markdown documentation (code examples) rather than actual executable code. The 'eval()' detections are PyTorch's model.eval() method, not dynamic code execution. Shell command patterns are documentation examples for batch processing workflows. No malicious intent, data exfiltration, or security vulnerabilities confirmed.

content.user_title: Analyze pathology slides with machine learning
content.value_statement: PathML streamlines computational pathology workflows by providing unified tools for loading diverse slide formats, preprocessing images, and training ML models. Researchers can analyze whole-slide images, build tissue graphs, and quantify multiplex immunofluorescence data in a single framework.
actual_capabilities: Load 160+ proprietary slide formats including SVS, NDPI, SCN
Apply stain normalization and tissue detection algorithms
Train HoVer-Net models for nucleus segmentation
Build spatial graphs from cellular relationships
Analyze CODEX and multiplex immunofluorescence data
Export results to standard formats like HDF5 and AnnData
limitations: Requires significant computational resources for large WSI files
GPL-2.0 license may restrict commercial usage
Specialized domain knowledge needed for parameter tuning
Limited to 2D pathology images, no 3D volume support

use_cases.title: Segment nuclei in H&E stained tissues
use_cases.description: Load whole-slide images, apply preprocessing pipelines, and use HoVer-Net to detect and classify cell nuclei for quantitative analysis.

use_cases.title: Analyze CODEX multiplex imaging data
use_cases.description: Process multi-run CODEX experiments, segment cells with Mesmer, and quantify protein marker expression for spatial proteomics.

use_cases.title: Train custom pathology models
use_cases.description: Use PathML's PyTorch integration to train deep learning models on public datasets like PanNuke with optimized data loading.

prompt_templates.title: Basic WSI loading
prompt_templates.scenario: Load and visualize a pathology slide
prompt_templates.prompt: Load the SVS file at data/slide.svs using PathML and display the image pyramid structure. Show me what levels are available and their dimensions.

prompt_templates.title: Preprocessing pipeline
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a PathML pipeline that detects tissue regions, normalizes H&E stains using Macenko method, and removes artifacts from slide.svs

prompt_templates.title: Nucleus segmentation
prompt_templates.prompt: Use PathML's HoVer-Net model to segment nuclei in the preprocessed slide. Extract segmentation masks and classify nucleus types.

prompt_templates.title: Build tissue graphs
prompt_templates.prompt: From the segmented nuclei, construct a spatial graph where nodes are cells and edges connect neighboring cells. Extract graph features for downstream analysis.

best_practices: Always use appropriate slide class for your image format (SVSSlide, CODEXSlide, etc.)
Generate tiles at appropriate resolution for your analysis - use level parameter to balance detail vs performance
Apply stain normalization before training ML models to reduce batch effects
anti_patterns: Don't load entire WSI into memory - use tiling and memory mapping for large slides
Avoid training models on unnormalized images from different scanners or labs
Don't use generic image loading libraries - PathML handles metadata and pyramid levels correctly

faq.question: What slide formats does PathML support?
faq.answer: PathML supports 160+ formats including Aperio SVS, Hamamatsu NDPI, Leica SCN, Zeiss formats, DICOM, and standard TIFF.

faq.question: How do I handle memory issues with large slides?
faq.answer: Use tile-based processing with generate_tiles(), specify appropriate level parameter, and save intermediate results to HDF5.

faq.question: Can PathML train custom deep learning models?
faq.answer: Yes, PathML integrates with PyTorch and provides pre-built models like HoVer-Net. You can also implement custom architectures.

faq.question: What is the difference between HoVer-Net and HACT-Net?
faq.answer: HoVer-Net segments individual nuclei, while HACT-Net classifies cell types hierarchically across tissue regions.

faq.question: How do I analyze CODEX multiplex data?
faq.answer: Use CODEXSlide class, collapse multi-run data, segment with Mesmer, then quantify marker expression per cell.

faq.question: Can I use PathML for commercial projects?
faq.answer: PathML uses GPL-2.0 license which may have restrictions. Check license terms for commercial usage requirements.
